Hi:
 Perhaps it is only the Japanese mind set, but isn't it analogous to a
koshirae that fails shinsa because the menuki were replaced, or even the
hilt rewrapped?  How about a sword that is retempered, or more closely
that is downgraded because the horimono is atoh-bori? What about a
Rembrandt that some later artist "improved" by brightening up one of
those dark backgrounds? Sword polishing is reductive, these other things
are additive.
 Arnold Frenzel

> Jim,
>  While making copies for the Chicago shinsa,I notice an iron tsuba 
> got the pinkie ........reason given was the inlays were added later.
> Why is that ?  I mean if the soft metal inlays were added in the Edo 
> days, it was " fashionable " then and not meant to deceive .
> I recall that tsuba was a mumei.
> 

Very interested in the reply here. Seems to me a lot of
very good tsuba had inlay which were later applications.
Ko-Nara, Heianjo, etc commonly used Saotome tsuba as
starting points. Also most of the gomoku zogan and mukade
styles, the inlay or wire is a later addition. I'm sure
many other examples could be cited. Does that
mean none of those are eligible for papers?

Rich S
